subject: Testing with various log levels
msgSnippet: I want to execute my unit tests with both logging set to DEBUG and then execute them again with logging set to FATAL.   This is to ensure that no bugs
messageBody:
I want to execute my unit tests with both logging set to DEBUG and
then execute them again with logging set to FATAL. This is to
ensure that no bugs exist/are introduced that will be exhibited only
when logging is set to a certain level. An example of such a bug
might be:

If (log.isInfoEnabled())
log.info("Using sequence: " + (seq++));

So, this code works fine as long as info level logging is enabled
for this class. Let's say one day in production, we decide to
reduce the spam generated by this class by bumping up the log level
to WARN. All of a sudden, things start failing, etc.

So, let's say this code exists inside class Foo. I can test both
ends of the spectrum by doing something like:

public class FooDebugTest extends TestCase
{
protected void setUp() throws Exception()
{
Logger.getLog(Foo.class).setLevel(Level.DEBUG);
}

... tests
}

public class FooFatalTest extends FooDebugTest
{
protected void setUp() throws Exception()
{
Logger.getLog(Foo.class).setLevel(Level.FATAL);
}
}


Or, I can create an abstract class BaseFooTest and extend it with
FooDebugTest and FooFatalTest.

Either way, is there something more clever that I can do to
accomplish my goal of testing min/max logging levels?
